answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some links that may be helpful in answering your question.
The American Institute of CPA’s wrote a report on,  “Reward & Compensation & Incentives: Pay-for-Performance.” Page ten lists suggestions for non-monetary rewards.
http://www.aicpa.org/InterestAreas/PrivateCompaniesPracticeSection/Resources/HumanCapitalCenter/DownloadableDocuments/2254L378_PCPS_HC_Reward_Compensation_Incentives.pdf 
I have also included a couple of articles about best practices for pay for performance programs, which could also be helpful to consider.
Issues to Consider in Implementing a Pay-For-Performance Program:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301413/Issues_to_Consider_in_Implementing_a_PayForPerformance_Program
Merit Pay Can Be a Hard Sell:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/7163/Merit_Pay_Can_Be_a_Hard_Sell
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

answers.author: Albert Tripp
answers.text:
Brian:
We recently removed our pay for performance program.  In our case, the majority of staff receive the performance increase from year to year and the perception of it became confusing.  It was viewed as a COLA.  As an alternative, we are  exploring models that are meaningful among our staff to serve as a future incentive for performance.

author: Brian Chapman
text: I was just curious to see if there are any municipalities that use non-monetary incentives as meaningful rewards for their pay for performance program, such as time off. If you could share any ideas or practices, I would appreciate it.  Thanks.
title: Pay for Performance - Incentives
